leaders.name: Balendra Shah
leaders.biography:
Balendra Shah, popularly known as **Balen Shah**, is a Nepalese rapper, structural engineer, and politician who became the **first independent Mayor of Kathmandu** in 2022. Known for his bold reforms, direct-action governance, and outspoken personality, Shah has emerged as a symbol of change in Nepalese politics, inspiring youth while attracting both admiration and criticism.[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balen_Shah)[2](https://www.sourcenepal.com/balen-shah/)

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Balendra Shah was born on **April 27, 1990**, in **Naradevi, Kathmandu**, to **Ram Narayan Shah**, an Ayurvedic practitioner, and **Dhruvadevi Shah**. His family originally hailed from Mahottari District in Madhesh Province before moving to Kathmandu.[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balen_Shah)[2](https://www.sourcenepal.com/balen-shah/)  

He completed his schooling at **V.S. Niketan Higher Secondary School** and earned a **Bachelor’s degree in Civil Engineering** from Himalayan White House Institute of Technology (affiliated with Purbanchal University). Later, he pursued a **Master’s in Structural Engineering** from **Visvesvaraya Technological University (VTU)** in Karnataka, India.[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balen_Shah)[2](https://www.sourcenepal.com/balen-shah/)  

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Shah entered politics as an **independent candidate** in the 2022 local elections, defeating candidates from major parties like Nepali Congress and CPN-UML to become **Kathmandu’s first independent mayor**. His campaign focused on **accountability, transparency, and practical governance**, leveraging his engineering background to propose data-driven solutions.[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balen_Shah)[2](https://www.sourcenepal.com/balen-shah/)  

### **Key Initiatives as Mayor**
- **Dozer Campaign:** Demolition of illegal structures and uncovering the buried Tukucha River.  
- **Transparency:** Introduced **live telecasts of municipal council meetings**.  
- **Waste Management:** Implemented systematic garbage collection and disposal reforms.  
- **Education Reform:** Launched **Textbook-free-Friday** in community schools to promote technical and extracurricular learning.  
- **Urban Development:** Enforced building code compliance, improved footpaths, and initiated campaigns to remove overhead wires.[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balen_Shah)[2](https://www.sourcenepal.com/balen-shah/)  

His leadership style is **direct and confrontational**, often bypassing traditional bureaucratic processes, which has both energized supporters and alarmed critics.[2](https://www.sourcenepal.com/balen-shah/)  

---

## **Strengths**
- **Symbol of Change:** Seen as a **youth icon** challenging Nepal’s traditional political culture.  
- **Technical Expertise:** Uses his engineering background for **data-driven urban planning**.  
- **Transparency Advocate:** Promotes open governance through live-streamed meetings.  
- **Bold Reforms:** Tackled entrenched issues like illegal encroachments and waste management.  
- **Cultural Preservation:** Initiatives to revive Newa culture and rename streets with original names.[2](https://www.sourcenepal.com/balen-shah/)[3](https://english.onlinekhabar.com/balen-shah-the-youths-icon-or-a-leader-too-confrontational-for-nepal.html)  

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Confrontational Style:** His unilateral decision-making often strains relations with the central government.  
- **Implementation Gaps:** Some ambitious projects, like making Kathmandu a 24-hour city and improving public transport, lag behind schedule.  
- **Handling of Crises:** Criticized for poor coordination during floods and delays in waste management solutions.  
- **Human Rights Concerns:** Accused of using excessive force against street vendors without providing alternatives.  
- **Legal Controversies:** Faced contempt of court charges for defying a court order on banning Indian films.[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balen_Shah)[3](https://english.onlinekhabar.com/balen-shah-the-youths-icon-or-a-leader-too-confrontational-for-nepal.html)

leaders.name: Hon. Pushpa Kamal Dahal (Prachanda)
leaders.biography:
Pushpa Kamal Dahal, widely known by his nickname **Prachanda** (meaning “fierce”), is a prominent Nepalese politician and revolutionary leader who played a pivotal role in abolishing Nepal’s monarchy and establishing a federal democratic republic. He has served as **Prime Minister of Nepal three times** (2008–2009, 2016–2017, and 2022–2024) and is currently the **Leader of the Opposition**. Prachanda is best known for leading the decade-long Maoist insurgency (1996–2006), which transformed Nepal’s political landscape. 

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Pushpa Kamal Dahal was born as **Ghanashyam Dahal** on **December 11, 1954**, in **Lewade, Dhikur Pokhari VDC, Kaski District**, Nepal, to **Muktiram Dahal** and **Bhawani Dahal**, in a poor Brahmin farming family. At the age of eight, his family migrated to **Chitwan District** in the Terai region. 

He completed his schooling in Chitwan and later enrolled at **Patan Multiple Campus** in Kathmandu for two years before returning to Chitwan. He earned a **Diploma in Agriculture Science** from the **Institute of Agriculture and Animal Science (IAAS), Tribhuvan University**, in Rampur, Chitwan, in 1975. Before entering full-time politics, Dahal worked as a **schoolteacher** and briefly with **USAID** in Jajarkot. 

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Prachanda’s political journey began in the early 1970s. He joined the **Communist Party of Nepal (Fourth Convention)** in 1978 and later became a key figure in the **Communist Party of Nepal (Mashal)**, rising to **General Secretary** in 1989. In 1994, he led a faction that became the **Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)**. 

### **Maoist Insurgency (1996–2006)**
On **February 13, 1996**, Prachanda launched the **People’s War**, a decade-long armed insurgency aimed at abolishing the monarchy and establishing a people’s republic. The conflict resulted in over **13,000 deaths** and widespread displacement. Prachanda remained underground for nearly 25 years, spending much of that time in India. 

### **Peace Process and Entry into Mainstream Politics**
In **2006**, Prachanda signed the **Comprehensive Peace Accord**, ending the civil war and integrating Maoists into mainstream politics. In the **2008 Constituent Assembly elections**, his party emerged as the largest, and Prachanda became **Nepal’s first Prime Minister of the Federal Democratic Republic** on **August 18, 2008**.

### **Prime Ministerial Tenures**
- **First Term (2008–2009):** Resigned after a dispute with the President over sacking the army chief.  
- **Second Term (2016–2017):** Formed a coalition with Nepali Congress; resigned as per power-sharing deal.  
- **Third Term (2022–2024):** Formed a coalition government but faced instability and was ousted after losing a confidence vote in July 2024. 

---

## **Strengths**
- **Revolutionary Leadership:** Successfully led a movement that ended Nepal’s 237-year-old monarchy.  
- **Negotiation Skills:** Played a central role in peace talks and drafting Nepal’s new constitution.  
- **Mass Mobilization:** Ability to rally marginalized communities and ethnic minorities.  
- **Political Resilience:** Maintained relevance through decades of political upheaval and multiple party splits. 

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Power-Centric Politics:** Accused of prioritizing personal power over governance, contributing to political instability. 
- **Corruption and Nepotism:** Criticized for favoring family members and close allies in political appointments.  
- **Lavish Lifestyle:** Faced backlash for luxury spending despite advocating equality and poverty eradication. [StarsUnfolded](https://starsunfolded.com/prachanda/)  
- **Human Rights Concerns:** His leadership during the insurgency was linked to human rights abuses and suppression of the press.  
- **Policy Failures:** Struggled to address poverty, inflation, and governance issues during his premierships.

leaders.name: Hon. Dr. Aarju Rana
leaders.biography:
Dr. Aarju Rana Deuba is a prominent Nepali politician, social activist, and psychologist, widely recognized for her advocacy on women’s rights, mental health, and social justice. She is a **Central Committee Member of the Nepali Congress** and has served as a **Member of Parliament**. Beyond politics, she is the founder of several influential NGOs and has played a key role in shaping gender and social policies in Nepal.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Aarju Rana Deuba was born on **January 26, 1962**, in **Kathmandu, Nepal**, into a Rana family with a strong social and political background. She completed her early education in Nepal before pursuing higher studies abroad.

- **Bachelor’s Degree:** Psychology from **St. Bede’s College**, Shimla, India  
- **Master’s Degree:** Clinical Psychology from **Punjab University**, Chandigarh, India  
- **Doctorate (Ph.D.):** Organizational Psychology from **Punjab University**  

Her academic background in psychology laid the foundation for her later work in mental health and social development.

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Dr. Aarju Rana Deuba entered active politics through the **Nepali Congress** and has been a **Central Committee Member** for several years. She served as a **Member of the House of Representatives** and has been actively involved in legislative work related to gender equality, social justice, and human rights.

### **Key Roles and Contributions**
- **Founder and Chairperson:**  
  - **SAATHI** – An NGO working against domestic violence and gender-based violence  
  - **Rural Women’s Development and Unity Center (RUWDUC)** – Focused on rural women’s empowerment  
- **International Engagement:**  
  - Served as **President of the International Center for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD)** Board  
  - Represented Nepal in numerous global forums on gender and development  

She has also been a strong advocate for **mental health awareness**, **women’s political participation**, and **child rights**.

---

## **Strengths**
- **Gender Equality Advocate:** Instrumental in pushing for laws and policies promoting women’s rights and representation.
- **Mental Health Expertise:** Uses her psychology background to influence social and health policies.
- **Global Perspective:** Represents Nepal in international platforms, strengthening Nepal’s voice on gender and development issues.
- **Institution Builder:** Founded and led multiple NGOs that have significantly impacted rural development and women’s empowerment.
- **Policy Influence:** Played a role in drafting gender-sensitive provisions in Nepal’s constitution and laws.

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Political Nepotism Allegations:** Often criticized for being associated with her husband, Sher Bahadur Deuba, former Prime Minister of Nepal, which some claim gives her undue political advantage.
- **Limited Electoral Success:** Despite her influence, she has faced challenges in winning direct elections.
- **Elite Background Criticism:** Some detractors argue that her privileged background limits her understanding of grassroots struggles.
- **NGO Funding Transparency:** Questions have occasionally been raised about the funding and operations of NGOs under her leadership, though no major legal issues have been proven.

---

leaders.name: Hon. Sumana Shrestha
leaders.biography:
Sumana Shrestha is a Nepali politician, entrepreneur, and activist, widely recognized for her data-driven governance approach and reformist agenda. She is a **Member of Parliament** representing the **Rastriya Swatantra Party (RSP)** and served as the **Minister of Education, Science, and Technology** from March to July 2024. Known for her global education and grassroots activism, Shrestha has emerged as a prominent voice for transparency, innovation, and systemic reform in Nepalese politics.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Sumana Shrestha was born on **October 1, 1984**, in **Kathmandu, Nepal**, into a middle-class family. She completed her early schooling at **Saraswati Boarding Higher Secondary School** in Chhetrapati and pursued her **A-Levels in Economics and Mathematics** at **Budhanilkantha School**.

She later moved to the United States for higher education, earning a **Bachelor of Arts in Economics and Mathematics** from **Bryn Mawr College** (with coursework at Haverford College), graduating **magna cum laude** in 2007. She then obtained an **MBA from the MIT Sloan School of Management**, equipping her with advanced management and analytical skills that would later influence her political career.

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Sumana Shrestha entered politics as a founding member of the **Rastriya Swatantra Party (RSP)** and was elected to the **House of Representatives** in December 2022 as a proportional representative for the indigenous community. She took her oath in **Nepal Bhasa**, signaling her commitment to cultural identity and inclusivity.

Within the RSP, she has served as:
- **Joint General Secretary** (until her resignation in 2025)
- **Central Committee Member**
- Chairperson of the **Education Department** and the **Science, Communication, and IT Department**

### **Ministerial Role**
In March 2024, Shrestha was appointed **Minister of Education, Science, and Technology** in the coalition government led by Prime Minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal. During her short tenure, she emphasized:
- **Digital Transformation in Education**
- **Curriculum Modernization**
- **Transparency in Teacher Recruitment**
- **STEM Education Promotion**

Her approach was characterized by **data-driven decision-making** and **policy innovation**, though her tenure ended in July 2024 due to political reshuffling.

### **Professional Background Before Politics**
Before entering politics, Shrestha worked as:
- **Management Consultant** at **Boston Consulting Group (BCG)**
- **Trader and Financial Analyst** at **Citigroup**
- **Head of Global Operations and Strategy** at **Fusemachines Inc.**

She also founded impactful initiatives such as:
- **Carpool Kathmandu** (to address fuel crisis and traffic congestion)
- **Medication for Nepal** (recognized at the 2016 Global Entrepreneurship Summit by President Barack Obama)

---

## **Strengths**
- **Global Perspective:** Combines international education and corporate experience with local activism.
- **Reform-Oriented Leadership:** Advocates for systemic reforms in education, governance, and technology.
- **Grassroots Engagement:** Actively involved in heritage conservation and disaster relief efforts.
- **Innovative Problem-Solving:** Introduced tech-driven solutions for social and infrastructural challenges.
- **Strong Communication Skills:** Known for articulate parliamentary speeches and bold stances on gender equality.

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Intra-Party Disputes:** Resigned from her role as Joint General Secretary in 2025, citing lack of internal democracy and transparency within RSP.
- **Short Ministerial Tenure:** Critics argue that her limited time as Education Minister restricted her ability to implement long-term reforms.
- **Perceived Elitism:** Some detractors claim her global background makes her disconnected from rural realities.
- **Factional Politics:** Her reformist stance has occasionally clashed with party leadership, fueling internal tensions.
- **Public Controversies:** Faced criticism for attire and personal choices, reflecting persistent gender biases in Nepali politics.
---

leaders.name: Harka Raj Rai
leaders.biography:
Harka Raj Rai, popularly known as **Harka Sampang**, is an independent Nepali politician, social activist, and the current **Mayor of Dharan Sub-Metropolitan City** since May 2022. Known for his grassroots activism, anti-corruption stance, and hands-on leadership style, Rai has become a symbol of independent politics in Nepal. His tenure has been marked by bold initiatives to address water scarcity, environmental issues, and governance reforms, as well as controversies over his confrontational approach.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Harka Raj Rai was born on **February 27, 1983**, in **Khartamchha, Khotang District** (present-day Kepilasgadhi Rural Municipality), Nepal. He grew up in a modest family; his father, **Til Bikram Rai**, was a former British Gurkha soldier. His upbringing in the hills instilled in him values of hard work and a deep connection to nature, which later influenced his activism.

He completed his **School Leaving Certificate (SLC)** in his village and moved to Dharan in 1998 for higher education. Rai earned a **Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) in English and Political Science** from **Mahendra Multiple Campus, Dharan**, and initially worked as a tutor. After graduation, he went abroad for employment, working in **Iraq and Afghanistan** for six years before returning to Nepal.

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Harka Sampang’s political journey began through **social activism** rather than party politics. After returning from abroad, he founded the **National Unity Network**, a platform to protest against corruption and advocate for good governance. He became widely known for his campaigns against:
- **Illegal sand extraction from rivers**
- **Tax hikes**
- **Water scarcity in Dharan**
- **Displacement caused by infrastructure projects**

He also coordinated efforts for people displaced by the **Madan Bhandari Inner Terai Highway** expansion and built **Shram Sanskriti Park** to preserve Dharan’s cultural heritage.

### **Electoral Politics**
- **2019:** Contested Dharan mayoral by-election as an independent candidate but secured only 422 votes.
- **2022:** Successfully elected as **Mayor of Dharan** as an independent candidate with the electoral symbol **“Walking Stick (Lauro)”**, defeating candidates from major parties. He received **20,821 votes (39.8%)**, defeating Nepali Congress and CPN-UML candidates.

---

## **Strengths**
- **Grassroots Leadership:** Known for his direct engagement with citizens and hands-on approach, often seen working on infrastructure projects himself.
- **Anti-Corruption Stance:** Advocates for transparency and accountability in local governance.
- **Environmental Advocacy:** Actively campaigns against illegal resource extraction and promotes sustainable development.
- **Water Management Initiatives:** Prioritizes solving Dharan’s chronic water shortage by mobilizing community labor and exploring new water sources.
- **Symbol of Independent Politics:** Represents a break from traditional party politics, inspiring youth and reformists.

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Confrontational Leadership Style:** Accused of bypassing legal protocols and clashing with the Deputy Mayor and municipal officials.
- **Controversies:**  
  - Alleged involvement in inciting an assault during a local dispute.  
  - Filed defamation cases against journalists critical of his governance.  
  - Investigated for unauthorized tree cutting in Dharan-20.  
- **Procedural Irregularities:** Criticized for unilateral decisions, such as appointing an acting mayor without following legal norms.
- **Populist Approach:** Some critics argue that his focus on symbolic acts overshadows long-term policy planning.
- **Media Relations:** His aggressive stance toward journalists has drawn negative attention, though he later issued public apologies.

---

leaders.name: Hon. Gagan Kumar Thapa
leaders.biography:
Gagan Kumar Thapa is a prominent Nepali politician, reformist, and youth leader currently serving as the **General Secretary of the Nepali Congress**. Known for his progressive stance, eloquent speeches, and advocacy for democratic reforms, Thapa has emerged as one of the most influential figures in Nepalese politics. He has served as a **Member of Parliament** since 2008 and was the **Minister of Health and Population** from 2016 to 2017. His leadership is marked by a strong focus on governance reforms, youth empowerment, and public health.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Gagan Thapa was born on **July 19, 1976**, in **Kathmandu, Nepal**, into a middle-class family with roots in Solukhumbu District. His father, **Mahendra Kumar Thapa**, worked as an engineer, and his mother, **Rameshwari Thapa**, was a homemaker. Raised in an environment that valued education and democratic ideals, Thapa developed an early interest in social justice and politics.

He completed his schooling at **Siddhartha Vanasthali School** in 1992 and earned a **Bachelor of Science in Chemistry** from **Tri-Chandra College** in 1998. Later, he pursued a **Master’s degree in Sociology** from **Tribhuvan University**, graduating in 2003. His academic background in science and social sciences shaped his analytical approach to governance and policy-making.

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Thapa began his political career as a **student activist** during the pro-democracy movement of the 1990s. He served as:
- **President of the Free Student Union** at Tri-Chandra College (1998–2000)
- **Vice President** of the Nepal Students Union (2000–2002)
- **General Secretary** of the Nepal Students Union (2002–2004)

He gained national prominence for his outspoken opposition to King Gyanendra’s royal takeover in 2005, which led to multiple arrests and his recognition as a **Prisoner of Conscience by Amnesty International**.

### **Mainstream Politics**
- **2008:** Elected to the **First Constituent Assembly** through proportional representation.
- **2013:** Won a seat in the **Second Constituent Assembly** from Kathmandu-4.
- **2016–2017:** Served as **Minister of Health and Population**, introducing reforms in health insurance and hospital governance.
- **2017 & 2022:** Re-elected as **Member of Parliament** from Kathmandu-4.
- **2021:** Elected **General Secretary of the Nepali Congress**, securing the highest votes among candidates for executive positions.

Thapa is widely regarded as a **future prime ministerial candidate** and a leading voice for institutional reform within the Nepali Congress.

---

## **Strengths**
- **Progressive Vision:** Advocates for transparency, accountability, and institutional reforms.
- **Youth Leadership:** Represents a new generation of leaders, inspiring young voters.
- **Policy Expertise:** Known for well-researched parliamentary speeches and policy proposals.
- **Health Sector Reforms:** Introduced health insurance programs and strengthened public health systems during his tenure as Health Minister.
- **Crisis Leadership:** Played a key role in legislative debates on governance, education, and healthcare.

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Factional Politics:** Accused of deepening internal divisions within the Nepali Congress due to his reformist stance.
- **Limited Executive Experience:** Critics argue that despite his popularity, he lacks experience in managing large-scale governance beyond the health ministry.
- **Overemphasis on Rhetoric:** Some observers believe his strong oratory skills overshadow practical implementation.
- **Ambitious Leadership Goals:** His bid for party leadership has been seen as premature by senior party members.

---

leaders.name: Sunita Dangol
leaders.biography:
Sunita Dangol is a young Nepali politician, cultural activist, and media professional currently serving as the **Deputy Mayor of Kathmandu Metropolitan City** since May 2022. Known for her advocacy for Newa heritage, language preservation, and inclusive governance, she represents a new generation of leaders in Nepalese politics. Her leadership style emphasizes consensus-building, cultural identity, and institutional reform.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Sunita Dangol was born on **May 18, 1993**, in **Kathmandu, Nepal**, to **Satu Dangol** and **Sangita Dangol** in a Newar family. She completed her schooling at **Laxmi Shikshya Sadan Higher Secondary School** and later pursued higher education in science and social work.

- **Bachelor’s Degree:** B.Sc. in Biotechnology from **SANN International College**, affiliated with **Purbanchal University**  
- **Master’s Degree:** M.A. in Social Work from **Tribhuvan University**  

Apart from academics, she gained recognition as **Miss Newa 2011**, which marked her early involvement in cultural promotion. She also founded **Callijatra**, a youth-led initiative to preserve indigenous scripts like Ranjana Lipi.

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Sunita Dangol entered politics during the **2022 Kathmandu municipal elections**. Initially, she announced her candidacy for **Mayor** as an independent candidate but later joined the **Communist Party of Nepal (Unified Marxist–Leninist)** (CPN-UML) and contested for **Deputy Mayor** alongside mayoral candidate Keshav Sthapit.

She won the election with **68,612 votes (53.2%)**, defeating candidates from major political alliances and independents, making her one of the youngest deputy mayors in Nepal.

### **Roles and Initiatives as Deputy Mayor**
- **Judicial Functions:** Strengthened ward-level judicial committees and introduced **free legal aid programs** in all wards.
- **Cultural Preservation:** Promoted Newa heritage and language through municipal programs.
- **Women and Youth Empowerment:** Advocated for gender equality and youth participation in governance.
- **Consensus Building:** Played a key role in mediating political deadlocks within Kathmandu Metropolitan City, especially during disputes between the Mayor and federal government.
- **Digital Governance:** Supported initiatives for e-governance and transparency in municipal operations.

---

## **Strengths**
- **Consensus-Oriented Leadership:** Known for bridging divides between political factions and promoting dialogue.
- **Cultural Advocacy:** Strong proponent of Newa heritage, indigenous scripts, and language preservation.
- **Youth Representation:** Symbolizes generational change in Nepalese politics, inspiring young voters.
- **Institutional Reforms:** Expanded the role of Deputy Mayor beyond ceremonial duties to include judicial and social functions.
- **Global Recognition:** Selected as a **World Economic Forum Young Global Leader (2025)** for her contributions to inclusive governance.

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Limited Executive Power:** As Deputy Mayor, her role is often constrained by legal and structural limitations, leading to criticism of her effectiveness.
- **Party Affiliation Shift:** Initially projected as an independent candidate, her decision to join CPN-UML drew skepticism from some supporters.
- **Perceived Symbolism:** Critics argue that her cultural activism sometimes overshadows pressing urban governance issues.
- **Media Scrutiny:** Faced criticism for balancing ceremonial roles with substantive policy-making responsibilities.

---

leaders.name: Ram Chandra Paudel
leaders.biography: Third President of Nepal since March 2023; former Speaker, Deputy Prime Minister, and senior leader of Nepali Congress; long-time democracy activist.

leaders.name: Bidya Devi Bhandari
leaders.biography: Second President of Nepal (2015–2023); first female head of state; former Minister of Defence and Environment.

leaders.name: Sagar Dhakal
leaders.biography:
Sagar Dhakal is a Nepali politician, hydropower engineer, and youth activist who gained national attention as an **independent candidate** in the 2022 general elections from **Dadeldhura**, challenging veteran leader Sher Bahadur Deuba. Known for his reformist vision, global academic background, and outspoken stance against corruption, Dhakal represents a new wave of educated, independent-minded leaders in Nepalese politics.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Sagar Dhakal was born in **Dadeldhura District**, Sudurpashchim Province, Nepal, into a modest family. He completed his early schooling in local institutions before pursuing higher education in engineering.

- **Undergraduate:** Studied **Hydro-Mechanical Engineering** in Nepal on a full scholarship, ranking among the top 5 out of 12,000 students in the entrance exam.
- **Master’s Degree:** **MSc in Water Science, Policy, and Management** from the **University of Oxford**, UK, as an Oxford-Weidenfeld and Hoffmann Scholar.
- **Academic Achievements:**  
  - Published research papers on hydropower and water resource management in peer-reviewed journals.  
  - Authored **seven educational books** on Physics and Mathematics for Nepali students, selling over 25,000 copies.  
  - Secured research grants totaling over **USD 100,000** during his academic career.

Before entering politics, Dhakal worked as a **hydropower engineer** on major projects, including the **410 MW Nalsing Gad Storage Hydropower Project**, collaborating with international firms like MWH (USA) and SMEC (Australia).

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Sagar Dhakal entered politics as a **reformist independent candidate** in the **2022 House of Representatives election** from **Dadeldhura**, a constituency long dominated by Sher Bahadur Deuba. His candidacy symbolized a challenge to entrenched political elites and a call for generational change.

### **Political Highlights**
- **2022 General Election:** Contested as an independent candidate, securing significant votes despite limited resources and organizational backing.
- **Advocacy:** Focused on anti-corruption, good governance, and youth empowerment.
- **Public Engagement:** Leveraged social media and grassroots campaigns to connect with voters, emphasizing transparency and accountability.

---

## **Strengths**
- **Global Perspective:** Combines international education with local experience in infrastructure and development.
- **Policy Expertise:** Strong background in water resource management, energy policy, and sustainable development.
- **Youth Icon:** Represents a new generation of leaders advocating for systemic reforms.
- **Communication Skills:** Known for articulate speeches and ability to engage with diverse audiences.
- **Integrity and Transparency:** Advocates for clean politics and evidence-based governance.

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Political Inexperience:** Critics argue that his lack of prior political office limits his ability to navigate Nepal’s complex political landscape.
- **Populist Label:** Some accuse him of capitalizing on anti-establishment sentiment without a fully detailed policy roadmap.
- **Factional Tensions:** His independent stance has occasionally led to friction with mainstream political actors.
- **Overemphasis on Symbolism:** Detractors claim his campaigns focus more on rhetoric than actionable strategies.
- **High Expectations:** Supporters’ hopes for rapid change may be difficult to meet given systemic constraints.

---

leaders.name: Hon. Sobita Gautam
leaders.biography:
Sobita Gautam is a young Nepali politician, lawyer, and social activist who gained national prominence as a **Member of Parliament** representing the **Rastriya Swatantra Party (RSP)**. Known for her advocacy on youth issues, governance reforms, and gender equality, Gautam is one of the youngest parliamentarians in Nepal’s federal legislature. Her rise reflects the growing influence of educated, reform-oriented leaders in Nepalese politics.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Sobita Gautam was born on **November 12, 1994**, in **Jhapa District**, Nepal. She completed her schooling in Jhapa before moving to Kathmandu for higher education.

- **Bachelor’s Degree:** Law (LL.B.) from **Tribhuvan University**  
- **Master’s Degree:** Pursuing **LL.M. in International Law** (as of 2023)  

Gautam has been active in legal advocacy and youth leadership since her student days, focusing on constitutional law, governance, and social justice.

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Sobita Gautam entered politics through the **Rastriya Swatantra Party (RSP)** and contested the **2022 House of Representatives election** from **Kathmandu-2**, defeating senior leaders from traditional parties. Her victory marked a generational shift in Nepali politics.

### **Parliamentary Role**
- Serves as a **Member of the House of Representatives** since December 2022.
- Active in parliamentary committees related to **law, justice, and governance**.
- Advocates for **youth participation**, **anti-corruption measures**, and **digital governance**.

### **Professional Background**
Before politics, Gautam worked as:
- **Legal Practitioner:** Specialized in constitutional and administrative law.
- **Media Personality:** Hosted legal awareness programs on television and social media.
- **Youth Activist:** Engaged in campaigns for education reform, women’s rights, and civic awareness.

---

## **Strengths**
- **Youth Representation:** Symbolizes generational change and inspires young voters.
- **Legal Expertise:** Brings a strong understanding of constitutional and governance issues.
- **Communication Skills:** Known for clear, articulate speeches and active social media presence.
- **Gender Advocacy:** Promotes women’s participation in politics and leadership roles.
- **Reformist Vision:** Supports transparency, accountability, and institutional modernization.

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Political Inexperience:** Critics argue that her limited experience in governance may hinder policy implementation.
- **Factional Politics:** Involved in internal disputes within RSP, including leadership controversies.
- **Media Scrutiny:** Her personal life and public statements have occasionally attracted sensational coverage.
- **High Expectations:** Faces pressure to deliver rapid reforms in a system resistant to change.
- **Perceived Populism:** Some detractors claim her rhetoric outpaces practical solutions.

---

leaders.name: Baburam Bhattarai
leaders.biography:
Baburam Bhattarai is a prominent Nepali politician, architect, and former guerrilla leader who served as the **35th Prime Minister of Nepal** from **August 2011 to March 2013**. A key ideologue of the Maoist movement, Bhattarai played a central role in Nepal’s decade-long civil war and the subsequent transition from monarchy to a federal democratic republic. Known for his intellectual rigor and reformist vision, he later embraced democratic socialism and founded new political platforms, including **Naya Shakti Party** and the **Nepal Socialist Party**.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Baburam Bhattarai was born on **June 18, 1954**, in **Khoplang, Gorkha District**, Nepal, into a poor peasant family. Despite his humble background, he excelled academically:
- Ranked **first in Nepal** in the **School Leaving Certificate (SLC) exam** in 1970.
- Completed **Intermediate Science** at **Amrit Science College**, Kathmandu, topping the board exams.
- Received a **Colombo Plan scholarship** to study in India.

### **Higher Education**
- **B.Arch. in Architecture:** Punjab University, Chandigarh (1977)  
- **M.Tech. in Planning:** School of Planning and Architecture, New Delhi (1979)  
- **Ph.D. in Regional Development Planning:** Jawaharlal Nehru University (1986)  
  - Doctoral thesis later published as *The Nature of Underdevelopment and Regional Structure of Nepal: A Marxist Analysis* (2003).

During his student years in India, Bhattarai became politically active, founding the **All India Nepalese Students’ Association** and joining leftist movements.

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
### **Early Political Career**
- Joined the **Communist Party of Nepal (Fourth Convention)** in 1981.
- Became a key leader in the **CPN (Unity Centre)** in 1990.
- In 1994, co-founded the **Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)** with Pushpa Kamal Dahal (Prachanda).

### **Maoist Insurgency (1996–2006)**
- Played a central role in launching the **People’s War** in 1996, aimed at abolishing the monarchy and establishing a people’s republic.
- Served as the **chief ideologue** and political strategist of the Maoist movement.
- Represented Maoists in peace negotiations with the government in the early 2000s.

### **Mainstream Politics**
- **2008:** Elected to the **Constituent Assembly** from Gorkha and appointed **Minister of Finance** in the Maoist-led government.
- **2011–2013:** Served as **Prime Minister of Nepal**, focusing on constitution drafting and peace process implementation.
- Resigned in March 2013 after failing to achieve consensus on the new constitution.

### **Post-Maoist Politics**
- **2015:** Resigned from the Maoist party and launched **Naya Shakti Party** in 2016, advocating for progressive democratic socialism.
- **2019:** Merged Naya Shakti with Federal Socialist Forum to form **Samajbadi Party, Nepal**.
- **2022:** Became **Chairperson of Nepal Socialist Party**, promoting federalism, proportional representation, and transitional justice reforms.

---

## **Strengths**
- **Intellectual Leadership:** Recognized as one of Nepal’s most scholarly politicians, with deep expertise in development economics and planning.
- **Visionary Reformer:** Advocates for inclusive governance, federalism, and social justice.
- **Peace Negotiator:** Played a key role in ending the civil war and integrating Maoists into mainstream politics.
- **Policy Expertise:** Introduced progressive economic and social policies during his tenure as Finance Minister and Prime Minister.
- **Institution Builder:** Founded multiple political platforms to challenge traditional party structures.

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Civil War Legacy:** Held responsible for violence and human rights violations during the Maoist insurgency.
- **Governance Challenges:** Criticized for failing to deliver a new constitution during his premiership.
- **Frequent Party Switching:** Accused of political opportunism for leaving the Maoist party and forming new parties.
- **Ideological Shifts:** Transition from hardline Maoism to democratic socialism has drawn skepticism from both supporters and critics.
- **Limited Electoral Success:** Despite influence, his new parties have struggled to achieve major electoral victories.

---

leaders.name: Chiri Babu Maharjan
leaders.biography:
Chiri Babu Maharjan is a seasoned Nepali politician and the current **Mayor of Lalitpur Metropolitan City**, serving since **2017**. A member of the **Nepali Congress**, he is widely recognized for his focus on urban development, heritage conservation, and participatory governance. Maharjan has played a pivotal role in modernizing Lalitpur while preserving its rich cultural heritage.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Chiri Babu Maharjan was born on **December 1, 1957**, in **Lalitpur, Nepal**, into a Newar family deeply rooted in the cultural traditions of the Kathmandu Valley. He completed his schooling in Lalitpur and pursued higher education in Nepal.

- **Bachelor’s Degree:** Political Science from **Tribhuvan University**  
- **Master’s Degree:** Public Administration from **Tribhuvan University**  

His academic background in governance and administration shaped his approach to municipal leadership.

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Maharjan began his political career as a grassroots activist in the **Nepali Congress** during the pro-democracy movement. Over the years, he held various positions within the party and local government.

### **Key Political Roles**
- **1992–1997:** Elected **Mayor of Lalitpur Sub-Metropolitan City** for the first time, focusing on basic infrastructure and urban planning.
- **2017:** Elected as the **first Mayor of Lalitpur Metropolitan City** after the restructuring of local bodies under the federal system.
- **2022:** Re-elected as Mayor with a strong mandate, defeating independent and party-backed candidates.

### **Major Initiatives as Mayor**
- **Heritage Conservation:** Implemented programs to restore historic temples, courtyards, and traditional water spouts (hiti).
- **Smart City Projects:** Introduced digital governance tools, including online tax payment and e-permit systems.
- **Urban Infrastructure:** Expanded road networks, improved drainage systems, and promoted green spaces.
- **Waste Management:** Launched initiatives for systematic garbage collection and recycling.
- **Public Participation:** Encouraged citizen engagement in planning and budgeting processes.

---

## **Strengths**
- **Visionary Urban Planning:** Advocates for sustainable development while preserving cultural heritage.
- **Administrative Experience:** Decades of experience in local governance and public administration.
- **Consensus Builder:** Known for maintaining good relations across political parties and civil society.
- **Transparency and Accountability:** Promotes open governance and citizen participation.
- **Cultural Advocacy:** Strong commitment to protecting Newar heritage and traditional architecture.

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Slow Implementation:** Some critics argue that his ambitious projects face delays due to bureaucratic hurdles.
- **Limited Innovation:** Accused of relying on traditional governance models rather than adopting bold reforms.
- **Traffic and Pollution Issues:** Despite improvements, Lalitpur continues to struggle with congestion and air quality.
- **Resource Constraints:** Critics claim that his administration has not fully leveraged private sector partnerships for urban development.
- **Political Allegiance:** Occasionally criticized for prioritizing party interests over independent decision-making.

---

leaders.name: Renu Dahal
leaders.biography:
Renu Dahal is a prominent Nepali politician and the current **Mayor of Bharatpur Metropolitan City**, serving since **2017**. A senior leader of the **Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist Centre)**, she is the daughter of former Prime Minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal (Prachanda). Known for her focus on urban development, social welfare, and women’s empowerment, Renu Dahal has played a significant role in local governance and party politics.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Renu Dahal was born on **July 4, 1976**, in **Chitwan District**, Nepal, into a politically active family. Her father, Pushpa Kamal Dahal, is a key figure in Nepal’s political transformation. Growing up during a period of political upheaval, she was exposed to leftist ideology from an early age.

- **Schooling:** Completed primary and secondary education in Chitwan.
- **Higher Education:** Holds a **Bachelor’s Degree in Education** from **Tribhuvan University**.

Her academic background and family environment shaped her interest in politics and social activism.

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Renu Dahal began her political career as a member of the **All Nepal Women’s Association (Revolutionary)**, the women’s wing of the Maoist party. She later became active in mainstream politics after the peace process.

### **Key Political Roles**
- **2008:** Elected as a **Member of the Constituent Assembly** through proportional representation from the Maoist Centre.
- **2017:** Elected as **Mayor of Bharatpur Metropolitan City**, defeating Devi Gyawali of CPN-UML in a closely contested race.
- **2022:** Re-elected as Mayor for a second term, securing a strong mandate.

### **Major Initiatives as Mayor**
- **Urban Infrastructure:** Expanded road networks, improved drainage systems, and initiated smart city projects.
- **Health and Education:** Upgraded municipal hospitals and introduced scholarship programs for underprivileged students.
- **Tourism Development:** Promoted Bharatpur as a gateway to Chitwan National Park and a hub for eco-tourism.
- **Women’s Empowerment:** Launched programs for women entrepreneurs and gender equality in local governance.
- **Digital Governance:** Implemented e-governance tools for tax collection and service delivery.

---

## **Strengths**
- **Grassroots Connection:** Strong ties with local communities and women’s groups.
- **Administrative Experience:** Two-term mayor with a track record in urban development.
- **Party Leadership:** Influential figure within the Maoist Centre, shaping local and national strategies.
- **Social Welfare Focus:** Advocates for inclusive development and poverty reduction.
- **Consensus Builder:** Known for coalition-building skills during local elections.

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Dynastic Politics:** Criticized for benefiting from her father’s political influence.
- **Controversial Election Practices:** Faced allegations of irregularities during the 2017 Bharatpur mayoral election, including ballot disputes.
- **Slow Project Implementation:** Accused of delays in major infrastructure projects.
- **Limited Transparency:** Critics argue that municipal governance under her leadership lacks full accountability.
- **Factional Politics:** Involved in internal party disputes, reflecting broader Maoist factionalism.

---

leaders.name: Rabindra Mishra
leaders.biography:
Rabindra Mishra is a Nepali politician, writer, philanthropist, and former journalist, best known as the **founder of Bibeksheel Nepali Party** and later a senior leader of the **Rastriya Prajatantra Party (RPP)**. Before entering politics, he served as the **Editor-in-Chief of BBC Nepali Service** and founded the social initiative **Help Nepal Network**. Mishra is recognized for his advocacy of good governance, nationalism, and economic reforms, as well as his controversial stance on monarchy and federalism.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Rabindra Mishra was born on **July 4, 1966**, in **Kathmandu, Nepal**, into a middle-class family originally from Siraha District. He completed his schooling at **Adarsha Vidya Mandir** and later attended **Tri-Chandra College** for his intermediate studies.

He pursued higher education abroad:
- **Bachelor’s Degree:** Journalism and English Literature from **Punjab University**, Chandigarh, India  
- **Master’s Degree:** International Relations from **University of Kent**, UK  

His academic background and exposure to global politics shaped his later career in journalism and politics.

---

## **Professional Career**
### **Journalism**
Mishra began his career as a journalist in Nepal before joining the **BBC Nepali Service**, where he worked for over two decades, eventually becoming **Editor-in-Chief**. During his tenure, he covered major political events, including the Maoist insurgency, peace process, and democratic transitions.

### **Social Work**
In 1999, he founded the **Help Nepal Network (HeNN)**, a global charity initiative promoting the slogan **“One Dollar a Month Fund for Nepal”**, which has funded schools, libraries, and health posts across rural Nepal.

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Rabindra Mishra entered politics in **2014**, founding the **Bibeksheel Nepali Party**, which later merged with Sajha Party to form **Bibeksheel Sajha Party** in 2017. He served as the party’s **Coordinator** and contested the **2017 general elections** from Kathmandu-1 but lost.

In **2022**, Mishra proposed a controversial **“Referendum on Monarchy and Federalism”**, arguing that Nepal’s federal structure was costly and ineffective. This stance created internal rifts, leading to his resignation from Bibeksheel Sajha Party.

In **July 2022**, he joined the **Rastriya Prajatantra Party (RPP)** as **Senior Vice President**, aligning with its pro-monarchy and Hindu state agenda. He contested the **2022 general elections** from Kathmandu-1 under RPP but was defeated.

---

## **Strengths**
- **Visionary Leadership:** Advocates for governance reforms, economic liberalization, and merit-based politics.
- **Media Influence:** Leveraged his journalism background to promote transparency and accountability.
- **Philanthropy:** Through Help Nepal Network, contributed significantly to rural education and health.
- **Strong Communication Skills:** Known for articulate speeches and writings on national issues.
- **Policy Advocacy:** Promotes nationalism, economic self-reliance, and anti-corruption measures.

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Ideological Shifts:** Criticized for moving from progressive politics to pro-monarchy positions, raising questions about consistency.
- **Electoral Defeats:** Despite popularity, has failed to secure a parliamentary seat in multiple elections.
- **Polarizing Stance:** His call for a referendum on monarchy and federalism sparked controversy and alienated some supporters.
- **Party Instability:** Frequent party splits and leadership disputes under his watch weakened his political base.
- **Perceived Elitism:** Critics argue that his urban-centric approach overlooks rural realities.

---

leaders.name: Hon. Rajendra Prasad Lingden
leaders.biography:
Rajendra Prasad Lingden is a Nepali politician, former **Deputy Prime Minister of Nepal**, and the current **Chairman of the Rastriya Prajatantra Party (RPP)**. Known for his strong nationalist stance and advocacy for constitutional monarchy and Hindu state, Lingden has emerged as a key figure in Nepal’s right-wing politics. He has served as a **Member of Parliament** since 2018 and briefly held the portfolio of **Minister of Energy, Water Resources, and Irrigation** in 2023.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Rajendra Prasad Lingden was born on **September 7, 1965**, in **Amarpur, Panchthar District**, Nepal, to **Man Prasad Lingden** and **Dhan Kumari Lingden**. He grew up in a modest family and developed an early interest in politics during his student years.

- **Education:** Completed his **Master’s Degree from Tribhuvan University** in political science and history.
- **Early Activism:** Began political involvement in the late 1970s through the **Rastrabadi Swatantra Vidhyarthi Mandal (Nationalist Independent Students’ Union)**.
- Married **Sita Thapa**; the couple has one daughter and two sons.

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Lingden’s political career spans decades within the **Rastriya Prajatantra Party (RPP)**, a pro-monarchy and Hindu nationalist party.

### **Key Roles**
- **District Leadership:** Served as **Jhapa District Secretary** of RPP in the early 1990s.
- **Parliamentary Career:**  
  - Elected to the **House of Representatives** from **Jhapa-3** in 2017 and re-elected in 2022, defeating senior Nepali Congress leader Krishna Prasad Sitaula both times.
- **Party Leadership:**  
  - **December 2021:** Elected **Chairman of RPP**, defeating long-time leader Kamal Thapa by over 200 votes.
- **Government Roles:**  
  - **Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Energy, Water Resources, and Irrigation** (January–February 2023) in the coalition government led by Pushpa Kamal Dahal.

### **Political Agenda**
- Advocates for **restoration of constitutional monarchy** and **declaration of Nepal as a Hindu state**.
- Promotes **nationalism, economic liberalization, and governance reforms**.
- Positions RPP as an alternative to mainstream parties like Nepali Congress and CPN-UML.

---

## **Strengths**
- **Grassroots Connection:** Strong base in Jhapa and eastern Nepal.
- **Organizational Skills:** Credited with revitalizing RPP and increasing its parliamentary presence to 14 seats in 2022.
- **Bold Leadership:** Willingness to challenge established leaders like Kamal Thapa and push for internal reforms.
- **Nationalist Appeal:** Resonates with voters seeking a return to traditional values and dissatisfaction with federalism.
- **Crisis Negotiator:** Played a role in coalition-building during government formation in 2023.

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Authoritarian Leadership Style:** Accused of sidelining senior leaders and centralizing power within RPP, leading to internal rifts.
- **Factionalism:** Ongoing disputes with leaders like Dhawal Shumsher Rana and Rabindra Mishra have weakened party unity.
- **Ideological Rigidity:** Critics argue that his insistence on monarchy and Hindu state alienates moderate voters.
- **Short Ministerial Tenure:** His brief stint as Deputy PM and Energy Minister was seen as politically symbolic rather than impactful.
- **Electoral Limitations:** Despite gains, RPP remains a minor player compared to major parties, limiting his national influence.

---

leaders.name: Hon. Bishwa Prakash Sharma
leaders.biography:
Bishwa Prakash Sharma is a prominent Nepali politician, reformist, and intellectual voice within the **Nepali Congress (NC)**. Currently serving as **General Secretary of NC** and **Member of Parliament from Jhapa-1**, Sharma is known for advocating democratic reforms, institutional accountability, and generational leadership change. His rise symbolizes a shift toward youth-driven politics in Nepal.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
- **Born:** December 21, 1970, in **Jhapa District**, Koshi Province, Nepal  
- **Parents:** Parshuram Sharma and Sabitri Sharma  
- **Education:**  
  - **Master’s Degree in Political Science** from **Tribhuvan University**  
- Developed political interest during school years; first arrested in **Class 9** for student activism.  

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
- **President:** Nepal Student Union (2000–2002)  
- **Spokesperson:** Nepali Congress (prior to 2021)  
- **General Secretary:** Elected in **2021 NC General Convention**, alongside Gagan Thapa  
- **Member of Parliament:** Elected from **Jhapa-1** in 2022, defeating senior UML leader Agni Kharel  

### **Political Agenda**
- Advocates for **internal party democracy**, **youth inclusion**, and **evidence-based governance**  
- Vocal on **anti-corruption**, **federalism**, and **inclusive development**  

---

## **Strengths**
- **Reformist Vision:** Pushes for modernization of NC and democratic accountability.  
- **Media Engagement:** Hosts TV program “Aaina” to discuss policy issues.  
- **Youth Leadership:** Represents generational change in Nepalese politics.  
- **Strong Oratory:** Known for articulate speeches and intellectual clarity.  

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Factional Politics:** Accused of deepening internal divisions within NC.  
- **Limited Executive Experience:** Critics question his ability to implement reforms beyond rhetoric.  
- **High Expectations:** Faces pressure to deliver rapid change in a traditional party structure.  
- **Perceived Elitism:** Some argue his urban-centric approach overlooks rural realities.  

---

leaders.name: Netra Bikram Chand (Biplav)
leaders.biography: Leader of the Communist Party of Nepal; former Maoist commander; led an armed struggle until 2020; currently coordinating the Socialist Front.

leaders.name: Bishwa Bhakta Dulal (Aahuti)
leaders.biography: Founder of the Scientific Socialist Communist Party, Nepal; previously associated with Janamorcha Nepal and CPN (Maoist Centre).

leaders.name: Sushila Karki
leaders.biography:
Sushila Karki (born 1952) is a Nepalese jurist and politician who made history as the first woman to serve as Chief Justice of Nepal’s Supreme Court (2016–2017). A strong anti-corruption voice with a reputation for integrity, she earned widespread respect during her tenure even as she drew sharp criticism from powerful interests. In September 2025, amid a youth-led anti-graft movement, Karki was tapped as a consensus choice for interim prime minister, becoming Nepal’s first female head of government. Her appointment underscored her standing as a nonpartisan reform figure in Nepali public life.

## Early Life and Education  
Sushila Karki was born on 7 June 1952 in Biratnagar (Morang District) in eastern Nepal. She was the eldest of seven children in a farming family. Karki earned a Bachelor of Arts at Mahendra Morang College (Tribhuvan University) in 1972 and a Master’s in political science from Banaras Hindu University (India) in 1975, then completed a law degree at Tribhuvan University in 1978. Early in her career she taught at Mahendra Multiple Campus in Dharan and practiced law in Biratnagar. During Nepal’s pro-democracy Jana Andolan of 1990, Karki participated in the street protests against the autocratic Panchayat regime and was briefly jailed in Biratnagar for her activism. These early experiences – and her academic training – helped shape her lifelong commitment to democracy and rule of law.

## Leadership and Political Positions  
She rose steadily through Nepal’s judicial ranks, becoming an ad-hoc justice of the Supreme Court in 2009 (confirmed in 2010). In July 2016 she was appointed Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, becoming Nepal’s first female Chief Justice. As Chief Justice she presided over several high-profile rulings, notably overturning the government’s appointment of a police chief and upholding graft convictions of senior officials. Her tenure was marked by an uncompromising stance against corruption, which earned her both respect and fierce pushback.  

In April 2017 the Maoist Centre and Nepali Congress parties filed an impeachment motion accusing Karki of bias after the court’s police-chief decision. Public protests and a Supreme Court order forced the legislature to withdraw the motion. Karki then retired on 6 June 2017, upon reaching Nepal’s mandatory retirement age for judges.  

After leaving the bench, Karki remained a prominent civic leader and legal commentator, writing and speaking on governance and the rule of law. In September 2025, amid nationwide demonstrations demanding action on corruption, Nepal’s youth (“Gen Z” movement) selected her as their preferred interim prime minister. She was sworn in on 12 September 2025, making Karki the first woman to lead Nepal’s government. Protest organizers and observers highlighted her reputation for honesty, judicial independence, and firm anti-corruption credentials in explaining her appointment.

## Strengths  
- **Anti-corruption record:** Widely known for her zero-tolerance stance on graft, Karki issued outspoken rulings against corruption and pursued cases against senior officials.  
- **Integrity and independence:** She built a reputation as an upright, impartial jurist. Many Nepalis view her as a principled outsider untainted by party politics.  
- **Trailblazer for women:** As the first female Chief Justice and later first female prime minister, she broke longstanding gender barriers, becoming a role model for women in law and governance.  
- **Nonpartisan credibility:** With no formal party affiliation, Karki is seen as a neutral figure acceptable to diverse groups in Nepal.  

## Criticism  
- **Impeachment controversy:** In 2017 leading politicians accused her of judicial overreach and bias, filing an impeachment motion that later collapsed under public pressure. Critics argued her forceful approach provoked unnecessary confrontation with the executive.  
- **Lack of political experience:** Karki is a career judge with no background in elected politics or government administration. Some observers warn that this could limit her effectiveness as an executive leader.  
- **Limited political base:** While embraced by anti-corruption activists and youth movements, she is not uniformly popular across Nepal’s fragmented political spectrum. Some established political groups were initially reluctant to support her appointment.

leaders.name: Mahabir Pun
leaders.biography:
Mahabir Pun (born January 22, 1955) is a Nepali social entrepreneur, educator, and innovator best known for introducing wireless internet to remote Himalayan villages and founding Nepal’s National Innovation Center. He received the Ramon Magsaysay Award in 2007 and was inducted into the Internet Hall of Fame in 2014. In 2025, he became Nepal’s Minister of Education, Science, and Technology.

---

### **Early Life and Education**
Mahabir Pun was born in Nangi Village, Myagdi District, a remote mountainous region of Nepal. His childhood was marked by poverty and limited educational resources. His father, a retired Gurkha soldier, moved the family to the plains for better schooling. Pun completed high school after significant struggles and worked as a teacher for over a decade to support his siblings’ education.

In 1989, he earned a partial scholarship to the University of Nebraska at Kearney, graduating in 1992 with a Bachelor’s in Science Education. Later, he completed a Master’s in Educational Administration at the University of Nebraska–Lincoln in 2001. These experiences shaped his vision of using technology to transform rural education.

---

### **Leadership and Political Positions**
- Founder, Nepal Wireless Networking Project (2002): Connected remote Himalayan villages to the internet, enabling e-learning, telemedicine, and local e-commerce.
- Founder, National Innovation Center (2012): Promotes grassroots innovation and research in Nepal.
- Minister of Education, Science, and Technology (2025–Present): Advocates for expanding research, innovation, and entrepreneurship.
- Advocacy: Led protests demanding at least 1% of Nepal’s budget for research and innovation and sold personal awards to fund projects like reviving the Agricultural Tools Factory.

---

### **Strengths**
- Visionary leadership in bridging the digital divide.
- Focus on practical, community-driven solutions.
- Global recognition through prestigious awards.
- Resilience and commitment, even selling medals and books to sustain projects.

---

### **Criticisms**
- Policy approach criticized as unrealistic for Nepal’s economic structure.
- Unconventional fundraising tactics drew mixed reactions.
- Known for blunt remarks and controversial positions, including criticism of government policies.

leaders.name: Rameshore Khanal
leaders.biography:
Rameshore Khanal (born June 16, 1956) is a Nepali economist, civil servant, and technocrat known for his integrity and reformist approach in public finance. He served as Finance Secretary and later became Nepal’s Finance Minister in 2025 under an interim government. Khanal is widely respected for his efforts in fiscal discipline, tax reforms, and transparency in governance.

---

### **Early Life and Education**
Born in Tansen, Palpa, Khanal grew up in a disciplined household that valued education and hard work. His childhood involved balancing rigorous studies with household chores. He displayed exceptional academic ability, once enrolling in three grades just days before exams and securing top positions.

Khanal pursued higher education in economics and accounting. He holds an MBA and Commerce degree from Tribhuvan University and is an Associate Chartered Management Accountant (India). He also attended international training programs on governance, budgeting, and cooperative management.

---

### **Leadership and Political Positions**
- **Civil Service Career (1980–2011):** Entered Nepal’s civil service at age 23, serving in cooperative development, auditing, and finance. Rose to become Finance Secretary, introducing reforms in tax policy, public procurement, and government accounting.
- **Board Roles:** Served on boards of Nepal Rastra Bank, Nepal Electricity Authority, Agricultural Development Bank, Nepal Telecom, and Nepal Airlines.
- **Finance Minister (2025–Present):** Appointed during a national economic crisis. Advocates fiscal discipline, scrapping fragmented projects, and implementing recommendations from the High-Level Economic Reform Commission.
- **Advisory Roles:** Former unpaid economic adviser to the Prime Minister and chair of reform commissions focused on transparency and investment.

---

### **Strengths**
- **Integrity and Discipline:** Known for refusing political pressure and prioritizing public interest.
- **Technocratic Expertise:** Deep knowledge of fiscal policy, budgeting, and economic reforms.
- **Crisis Management:** Played a key role in stabilizing revenue-to-GDP ratios and guiding Nepal through financial challenges.
- **Global Engagement:** Represented Nepal in international forums, including ADB and World Bank meetings.

---

### **Criticisms**
- **Rigid Approach:** His uncompromising stance on policy decisions has been viewed as inflexible by some political actors.
- **Limited Political Adaptability:** Critics argue that his technocratic style may clash with political realities, slowing consensus-building.
- **Public Expectations:** High expectations for rapid reforms in a short interim government tenure have raised concerns about feasibility.

---

leaders.name: Kulman Ghising
leaders.biography:
Kulman Ghising (born November 25, 1970) is a Nepali electrical engineer and reformist leader credited with ending Nepal’s chronic power outages. He served twice as Managing Director of the Nepal Electricity Authority (NEA) and, in 2025, was appointed Minister of Energy, Water Resources and Irrigation, as well as Minister of Physical Infrastructure and Urban Development in Nepal’s interim government. His leadership transformed Nepal’s energy sector, making the country nearly load-shedding-free and a net energy exporter.

---

### **Early Life and Education**
Kulman Ghising was born in **Bethan village, Ramechhap District**, in eastern Nepal. Raised in a modest family, he experienced firsthand the hardships of rural life without reliable electricity. He completed primary schooling in his village and later moved to Kathmandu for secondary education, graduating from Amar Adarsh Secondary School. He earned an Intermediate degree in Science from Amrit Science Campus.

Ghising received a scholarship to study **Electrical Engineering** at the Regional Institute of Technology, Jamshedpur, India. He later completed a **Master’s in Power Systems Engineering** from Pulchowk Engineering College and an **Executive MBA** from Pokhara University. These qualifications equipped him to tackle Nepal’s energy challenges.

---

### **Leadership and Political Positions**
- **Managing Director, Nepal Electricity Authority (2016–2020; 2021–2025):** Ended nationwide load-shedding, improved financial health of NEA, and expanded electricity access to 99% of households.
- **Energy Minister (2025–Present):** Oversees energy policy, hydropower development, and MCC Compact projects for infrastructure growth.
- **Infrastructure and Urban Development Minister (2025–Present):** Tasked with rebuilding and modernization efforts following political unrest.
- **Key Initiatives:** Advocated for recovering billions in unpaid dues from industries, promoted cross-border electricity trade, and strengthened Nepal-India energy ties.

---

### **Strengths**
- **Visionary Problem-Solver:** Eliminated up to 18-hour daily power cuts through strategic load management.
- **Technocratic Expertise:** Deep knowledge of hydropower, grid optimization, and energy economics.
- **Public Trust:** Widely admired for integrity, efficiency, and results-driven leadership.
- **Global Engagement:** Advanced Nepal’s energy diplomacy and export potential.

---

### **Criticisms**
- **Political Vulnerability:** Twice removed from NEA amid political interference, raising concerns about governance stability.
- **Rigid Policy Stance:** His uncompromising approach to recovering industrial dues sparked disputes with political leaders.
- **Performance Evaluation Controversy:** Received a “zero rating” in 2025, allegedly for delayed reporting—critics claim it was politically motivated.
- **Appointment Process:** Past NEA appointments criticized for lacking transparency and being politically influenced.

---

leaders.name: Om Prakash Aryal
leaders.biography:
Om Prakash Aryal is a Nepali constitutional lawyer and senior advocate who became Home Minister in 2025, recognized for high-profile public interest litigations and a rule-of-law agenda focused on accountability and anti-corruption. Aryal took charge of the Home Ministry in an interim cabinet in 2025 with vows to revive stalled corruption cases and strengthen institutional integrity. 

### Early life and education
Aryal hails from Gulmi District and pursued law at Nepal Law Campus under Tribhuvan University after an initial interest in music, later building a Supreme Court practice centered on constitutional and human rights litigation. His formative public service experience includes time at the National Human Rights Commission and advisory work with Kathmandu Metropolitan City, shaping a pragmatic rights-oriented outlook.

### Leadership and political positions
Upon assuming office, Aryal publicly committed to reopening corruption-related files stalled by political influence and highlighted enforcement against vandalism and property damage during protests as part of a rule-of-law posture. Reporting also notes diplomatic outreach and coordination mandates typical of the Home portfolio within Nepal’s interim governance context in late 2025.

### Strengths
- Landmark public interest litigation record, including the disqualification of CIAA chief Lokman Singh Karki, cementing a reputation for constitutionalism and accountability.  
- Consistent anti-corruption and rights advocacy with early ministerial signaling toward reviving sensitive investigations and improving legal enforcement coherence.  
- Experience bridging civil society, municipal governance, and national administration, aiding translation of legal principles into executive action.

### Criticisms
- Questions about adapting an adversarial courtroom style to collaborative executive governance amid protest management and security coordination challenges.  
- Political pushback and scrutiny from rivals and stakeholders regarding the pace and tone of early decisions in office within a polarized environment.

leaders.name: Hon. K.P. Sharma (Oli)
leaders.biography:
**Khadga Prasad Sharma Oli** (born 22 February 1952 in Iwa, Tehrathum) is a seasoned Nepali communist politician who has served as Prime Minister four times (Oct 2015–Aug 2016, Feb 2018–May/Jul 2021, and since July 2024). A veteran of Nepal’s Jhapa communist uprising, he survived 14 years underground and in prison before rising through the ranks of the CPN–UML. Known for his assertive nationalist stance—such as issuing a new political map and pivoting towards China—his leadership has led infrastructure initiatives and energy reforms. However, critics accuse him of authoritarianism, centralizing power, and practicing cronyism.

---

### **Early Life and Education**

Born into a farming household, Oli lost his mother to smallpox aged four and was raised by his grandmother. His family migrated to Jhapa, where he passed the SLC at Adarsha Secondary School in 1970. Inspired by Marxist–Leninist ideals and anti-Panchayat movements, he was encouraged early on by his uncle, Ramnath Dahal ([en.wikipedia.org][1]).

---

### **Political and Leadership Positions**

* **Jhapa rebellion & imprisonment (1970s–1987):** Joined communist activism in 1970, went underground, was arrested in 1973, and spent 14 years in prison—including four in solitary confinement—under the Panchayat regime ([kids.kiddle.co][2]).
* **Rise in CPN-UML:** After release, became a central committee member, co-founded the CPN–UML in 1991, served as Home Minister (1994–95), Deputy PM & Foreign Minister (2006–07), and was elected party chair in 2014 ([kids.kiddle.co][2]).
* **Prime Ministerial tenures:** First appointed in Oct 2015 after the new constitution, returned to office in Feb 2018, briefly reappointed in May 2021 by the president, and assumed office again in July 2024 through a coalition with Nepali Congress ([kids.kiddle.co][2]).
* **Falldown:** Allegedly responsible for the mass atrocity against youth-led protest against corruption that saw 50+ deaths and over 400 injured on September 08, 2025. Resigned and fled on September 09, 2025 unable to bear pressure from the Gen-Z led protest ([ictj.org][6]).

---

### **Strengths**

* **Decisive nationalism:** Took bold stances like issuing a revised map including disputed areas, and rebalanced Nepal’s foreign policy by engaging deeply with China ([reuters.com][3]).
* **Infrastructure & energy reforms:** Prioritized grid stability, expanded hydropower and road networks, and struck a petroleum deal with China after India’s blockade ([reuters.com][3]).
* **Charismatic resilience:** His long imprisonment, ideological survival, and self-presentation as a principled communist resonate with his supporters .

---

### **Criticisms**

* **Authoritarian tendencies:** Repeatedly accused of centralizing power, dissolving parliament (especially in 2020–21), and fostering personality-driven politics ([dawn.com][4]).
* **Cronyism and democratic erosion:** Critics argue he favors loyalists, shields allies from accountability, and undermines institutional norms .
* **Economic and governance concerns:** Detractors highlight slow delivery on promises, accusations of corruption (e.g., tea estate scandal), and handling of pandemic-related powers as problematic ([en.wikipedia.org][5]).

---

[1]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K._P._Sharma_Oli?utm_source=chatgpt.com "K. P. Sharma Oli"
[2]: https://kids.kiddle.co/K._P._Sharma_Oli?utm_source=chatgpt.com "K. P. Sharma Oli Facts for Kids"
[3]: https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/pivot-india-nepal-pm-visits-china-seek-investment-2024-12-03/?utm_source=chatgpt.com "In pivot from India, Nepal PM visits China to seek investment"
[4]: https://www.dawn.com/news/1845896?utm_source=chatgpt.com "KP Sharma Oli appointed new prime minister of Nepal - Dawn"
[5]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giri_Bandhu_Tea_Estate_Corruption?utm_source=chatgpt.com "Giri Bandhu Tea Estate Corruption"
[6]: https://www.ictj.org/latest-news/nepal-prime-minister-quits-after-deaths-protests-sparked-social-media-ban

leaders.name: Hon. Sher Bahadur Deuba
leaders.biography:
Sher Bahadur Deuba is a veteran Nepalese politician and leader of the **Nepali Congress** party. Known for his resilience and adaptability, he has served as the **Prime Minister of Nepal five times** (1995–1997, 2001–2002, 2004–2005, 2017–2018, and 2021–2022), making him one of the most experienced political figures in Nepal’s democratic history. His career spans over five decades, marked by leadership during critical transitions, including the restoration of democracy, peace negotiations, and federal restructuring.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Sher Bahadur Deuba was born on **June 13, 1946**, in **Ashigram village, Dadeldhura District**, in what is now Sudurpashchim Province, Nepal. Coming from a modest background in one of Nepal’s most remote and underdeveloped regions, Deuba experienced firsthand the challenges of rural life, which later shaped his political priorities.

He completed his primary education at **Ashigram Primary School** and secondary education at **Mahendra High School** and **Sitaram High School** in Doti. In 1963, he moved to Kathmandu for higher education and enrolled at **Tri-Chandra College**, affiliated with Tribhuvan University, where he earned degrees in **Humanities and Law**. Later, he pursued further studies at the **London School of Economics (LSE)** in the late 1980s, focusing on political science.

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Deuba began his political journey as a student activist in the 1960s. He was a founding member and the first elected president of the **Nepal Students’ Union** in 1971, the student wing of the Nepali Congress. His early activism against the autocratic Panchayat system led to multiple arrests and periods of imprisonment.

With the restoration of multiparty democracy in 1990, Deuba emerged as a prominent leader within the Nepali Congress. He served as **Minister of Home Affairs** from 1991 to 1994 under Prime Minister Girija Prasad Koirala. His reputation as a pragmatic leader grew during this period.

### **Prime Ministerial Tenures**
- **First Term (1995–1997):** Focused on economic liberalization and signed the **Mahakali Treaty** with India, which sparked both praise and controversy.
- **Second Term (2001–2002):** Took office during the Maoist insurgency and declared a state of emergency. His decision to dissolve Parliament in 2002 led to his dismissal by King Gyanendra.
- **Third Term (2004–2005):** Appointed by King Gyanendra but later dismissed during the royal coup.
- **Fourth Term (2017–2018):** Oversaw the first elections under the new federal constitution, completing all three tiers of elections (local, provincial, and federal).
- **Fifth Term (2021–2022):** Returned to power following a Supreme Court ruling that reinstated Parliament. His government managed the COVID-19 vaccination drive and faced challenges related to political instability.

Deuba has also served multiple times as **Leader of the Opposition** and has been the **President of the Nepali Congress** since 2016.

---

## **Strengths**
- **Democratic Resilience:** Played a key role in Nepal’s democratic movements and constitutional transitions.
- **Crisis Management:** Led the country during periods of political turmoil, insurgency, and constitutional change.
- **Consensus Builder:** Known for his ability to form coalition governments and maintain party unity.
- **Longevity in Politics:** Maintained relevance across decades despite political upheavals and internal party rivalries.

---

## **Criticisms**
- **Perceived Weak Leadership:** Often criticized for indecisiveness and failure to implement bold reforms.
- **Corruption Allegations:** Accused of tolerating corruption and nepotism within his party and government.
- **Handling of Governance:** Blamed for inefficiency and lack of vision in addressing economic and social challenges.
- **Party Factionalism:** His leadership has faced internal dissent, with critics accusing him of prioritizing personal power over institutional strengthening.
- **Controversial Decisions:** His move to dissolve Parliament in 2002 and reliance on royal appointments during the monarchy era remain contentious.

---

leaders.name: Hon. Dr. Swarnim Wagle
leaders.biography:
Dr. Swarnim Wagle is a renowned Nepali economist, policy expert, and politician currently serving as a **Member of Parliament** and **Vice-Chair of the Rastriya Swatantra Party (RSP)**. Known for his expertise in economic policy and governance, Wagle has held influential roles in Nepal’s development planning and international organizations, including the **United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)** and the **World Bank**. His career reflects a blend of academic excellence, global experience, and reformist political vision.

---

## **Early Life and Education**
Swarnim Wagle was born in **1975** in **Bungkot, Gorkha District**, Nepal, into a middle-class family. He completed his early schooling at **Budhanilkantha School** in Kathmandu, where he excelled academically, ranking second in the national SLC examination.

He pursued higher education at prestigious global institutions:
- **BSc (Economics):** London School of Economics (LSE), UK  
- **MPA in International Development:** Harvard University, USA  
- **Ph.D. in Economics:** Australian National University, Australia  

His academic journey was supported by scholarships, and he specialized in development economics, governance, and policy analysis.

---

## **Leadership and Political Positions**
Dr. Wagle’s career spans both **international development** and **national politics**:

### **International Roles**
- **Chief Economic Advisor (2020–2022):** UNDP Regional Bureau for Asia and the Pacific, New York, covering 36 countries.
- **Senior Economist:** World Bank and UN agencies for nearly two decades.
- **Chairperson:** Institute for Integrated Development Studies (IIDS), a leading South Asian think tank.

### **National Roles**
- **Vice-Chair:** National Planning Commission (2017–2018); Member for two terms (2014–2015, 2016–2017).
- **Post-Disaster Needs Assessment (PDNA) Co-Leader:** After the 2015 Nepal earthquake, mobilized billions in reconstruction pledges.
